p: Odo de Magdunensis mentions a mixture of mint, strong rue, tansy, and milk cooked in olive oil with virgin wax, made into a plaster and applied to the kidney area of women who could not deliver their child. This could be to relieve pain [ 83]. Still on the subject of ophthalmic afflictions, William Mackenzie (1791â€“1868), author of the Practical Treatise of the Diseases of the Eye, one of the first British textbooks of ophthalmology, used a formulation of peppermint water, camphorated spirits of opium tincture and borax as a local anesthetic to be applied to the lacrimal puncta prior to mechanical unblocking with a hair pencil [ 119].
